pitrou commented on issue #6154: ARROW-7531: [C++] Reduce header cost
URL: https://github.com/apache/arrow/pull/6154#issuecomment-572640769
 
 
   Running [Clang Build Analyzer](https://github.com/aras-p/ClangBuildAnalyzer) on git master:
   ```
   **** Time summary:
   Compilation (368 times):
     Parsing (frontend):          440.0 s
     Codegen & opts (backend):    123.6 s
   
   ```
   and on this PR:
   ```
   **** Time summary:
   Compilation (369 times):
     Parsing (frontend):          383.3 s
     Codegen & opts (backend):    124.1 s
   ```
   
   Note that the times measured are bit [unreliable](https://github.com/aras-p/ClangBuildAnalyzer/issues/28).

wesm commented on issue #6154: ARROW-7531: [C++] Reduce header cost
URL: https://github.com/apache/arrow/pull/6154#issuecomment-572674580
 
 
   > If so, then it means there's not much benefit in splitting header files (except possibly readability). Everyone will intuitively include array.h and builder.h.
   
   Well, there is the public API and then there is what headers we include in internal modules. It seems like the spirit of this PR is to reduce the amount of superfluously included code, which means we should split up array.h so each part can be included piecemeal. See http://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/ARROW-6052
 
----------------------------------------------------------------
This is an automated message from the Apache Git Service.
To respond to the message, please log on to GitHub and use the
URL above to go to the specific comment.

users@infra.apache.org

   > If so, then it means there's not much benefit in splitting header files (except possibly readability). Everyone will intuitively include array.h and builder.h.
   
   Well, there is the public API and then there is what headers we include in internal modules. It seems like the spirit of this PR is to reduce the amount of superfluously included code in internal modules, which means we should split up array.h so each part can be included piecemeal.  Review comment:
   Would maybe not including this these files be too onerous for developers?
   
   Another advantage of more fine-grained header files is the potentially the elimination of "not real cycles" between compilation units I mentioned on the bazel thread.
 
----------------------------------------------------------------

+// Licensed to the Apache Software Foundation (ASF) under one
+// or more contributor license agreements.  See the NOTICE file

+// regarding copyright ownership.  The ASF licenses this file

+// under the License.

+#pragma once
+
+#include <memory>
+
+#include "arrow/array.h"                  // IWYU pragma: export
 
 Review comment:
   My experience in Python would be that finer-grained includes / imports increase the likelihood of cycles. For example, `array_list.h` and `array_binary.h` might have a cyclic dependency between each other while a monolithic `array.h` would not have a cycle onto itself (of course, this is a fictional example).
 
----------------------------------------------------------------
This is an automated message from the Apache Git Service.
To respond to the message, please log on to GitHub and use the
URL above to go to the specific comment.
 
For queries about this service, please contact Infrastructure at:
users@infra.apache.org

wesm commented on issue #6154: ARROW-7531: [C++] Reduce header cost
URL: https://github.com/apache/arrow/pull/6154#issuecomment-574478566
 
 
   It seems to me that we should keep `arrow/array.h` and `arrow/builder.h` as batteries-included public APIs for downstream users of the project, but these should not use IWYU export (rather simply `keep`) so that IWYU will protest if an internal module includes `arrow/array.h` instead of more simply for example `arrow/array/array_base.h`. I think the objective should be to keep things orderly and minimal internally within the C++ codebase? 
   
   IWYU is a pain to keep well-configured to not spew out red herrings but it does help maintain some cleanliness with the includes if it is inspected frequently. Since we build cross-platform I don't think having a 100% clean IWYU build is going to be practical (it can be if you are Linux-only)
 
----------------------------------------------------------------
This is an automated message from the Apache Git Service.
To respond to the message, please log on to GitHub and use the
URL above to go to the specific comment.
 
For queries about this service, please contact Infrastructure at:
users@infra.apache.org

kszucs commented on issue #6154: ARROW-7531: [C++] Reduce header cost
URL: https://github.com/apache/arrow/pull/6154#issuecomment-576469921
 
 
   I also had difficult time with IWYU but didn't tune its configuration. IWYU is still installed in the lint image, and archery theoretically supports to run it, so the following should work:
   
   ```bash
   docker-compose run --rm ubuntu-lint /bin/bash -c "pip install -e /arrow/dev/archery && archery lint --with-iwyu true"
   ```
   
   cc @fsaintjacques 
 
----------------------------------------------------------------
